elements.content: A comparative investigation of the coordination behavior of an O4S2-donor macrocycle L with the thiaphilic soft metal ions Ag+, Cu+, Hg2+, and Pd2+ is reported. The X-ray structures of seven complexes (1–7) have been determined, and a range of structural types and coordination modes, including discrete to continuous forms, mono- to multinuclear, and endo- to exocyclic structures involving M–S bonds, are presented. First, reactions of L with AgClO4, Hg(NO3)2, and K2PdCl4 afforded the typical endocyclic 1:1 complexes [AgL]ClO4 (1) without anion binding, as well as [HgL(NO3)2] (2), and [PdLCl2] (3), with anion binding. Further reaction of the anion-free complex 1 with different spacer ligands (L′: dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane and bpp = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)piperazine) resulted in the formation of the interesting “dumbbell”-like complexes [Ag2 L 2(dabco)](ClO4)2 (4) and [Ag2 L 2(bpp)](ClO4)2 (5), exhibiting a [(LAg)-L′-(AgL)] arrangement, respectively. Furthermore, the straightforward one-pot reactions of L with AgClO4 in the presence of L′ also resulted in the isolation of the corresponding “dumbbell” complexes. Comparative NMR studies suggest the existence of corresponding structures of this type in solution. Contrasting with the discrete structures of 1–5, reactions of L with CuBr and AgSCN afforded a double-stranded 1D network {[(Cu2Br2)L 2]·2CH2Cl2} n (6) linked with a rhomboidal Cu2Br2 cluster and an endo-/exocyclic 1D network [Ag4 L 2(SCN)4] n (7), respectively. The latter complex features an unusual fishbone-like structure in which endocyclic silver(I) complexes are attached to a “looped” exocyclic backbone of type {Ag-(1,3-μ2-SCN)2-Ag-(1,1,3-μ3-SCN)-Ag} n via Ag-SCN bonds.

The X-ray structures of seven complexes (1-7) have been determined, and a range of structural types and coordination modes, including discrete to continuous forms, mono- to multinuclear, and endo- to exocyclic structures involving M-S bonds, are presented. First, reactions of L with AgClO4, Hg(NO3)2, and K2PdCl4 afforded the typical endocyclic 1:1 complexes [AgL]ClO4 (1) without anion binding, as well as [HgL(NO3)2] (2), and [PdLCl2] (3), with anion binding. Further reaction of the anion-free complex 1 with different spacer ligands (L': dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane and bpp = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)piperazine) resulted in the formation of the interesting "dumbbell"-like complexes [Ag2 L 2(dabco)](ClO4)2 (4) and [Ag2 L 2(bpp)](ClO4)2 (5), exhibiting a [(LAg)-L'-(AgL)] arrangement, respectively. Furthermore, the straightforward one-pot reactions of L with AgClO4 in the presence of L' also resulted in the isolation of the corresponding "dumbbell" complexes. The latter complex features an unusual fishbone-like structure in which endocyclic silver(I) complexes are attached to a "looped" exocyclic backbone of type {Ag-(1,3-μ2-SCN)2-Ag-(1,1,3-μ3-SCN)-Ag} n  via Ag-SCN bonds.

elements.content: Based on the assembly reactions of an O4S2-macrocycle with thiaphilic soft metal ions, a range of structural types and coordination modes, including discrete to continuous forms, mono- to multinuclear, and endo- to exocyclic ones, is reported.

elements.content: The field of supramolecular coordination chemistry based on macrocycles has advanced to a stage where it is often possible to control the self-assembled products such that specific topologies result. Thus, the careful selection of the building blocks including the macrocyclic ligand and the metal ion make it possible to prepare a large number of desired coordination topologies. Unlike the ubiquitous endocyclic coordination (metal-in-cavity) of the polyether macrocycles, thiamacrocycles frequently form exocyclic products in which the metal is bound outside the cavity due to the tendency of sulfur donors in such rings to adopt an exocyclic orientation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The field of supramolecular coordination chemistry based on macrocycles has advanced to a stage where it is often possible to control the self-assembled products such that specific topologies result. Thus, the careful selection of the building blocks including the macrocyclic ligand and the metal ion make it possible to prepare a large number of desired coordination topologies. Unlike the ubiquitous endocyclic coordination (metal-in-cavity) of the polyether macrocycles, thiamacrocycles frequently form exocyclic products in which the metal is bound outside the cavity due to the tendency of sulfur donors in such rings to adopt an exocyclic orientation.

elements.content: In fact, exocyclic coordination is attractive synthetically because it provides a means for preparing more elaborate network assemblies than would be possible to obtain through the use of endocoordination. Also, exocoordination can be employed as a tool for crystal engineering that is responsive to diverse controlling factors; in addition to the choice of the ligands and metal ions, other factors may also be important, such as the nature of the anion, the solvent, and the coligand. A range of structural types and coordination modes of thiamacrocycles, including discrete or continuous forms, mono- to multinuclear, and endo- or exocyclic systems, have now been reported and have also been reviewed by us.
elements.clean_text: In fact, exocyclic coordination is attractive synthetically because it provides a means for preparing more elaborate network assemblies than would be possible to obtain through the use of endocoordination. Also, exocoordination can be employed as a tool for crystal engineering that is responsive to diverse controlling factors; in addition to the choice of the ligands and metal ions, other factors may also be important, such as the nature of the anion, the solvent, and the coligand. A range of structural types and coordination modes of thiamacrocycles, including discrete or continuous forms, mono- to multinuclear, and endo- or exocyclic systems, have now been reported and have also been reviewed by us.

elements.content: Related to the exocoordination based networking of thiamacrocycles, we have recently communicated homo- and heteronuclear coordination polymers with different motifs which were obtained from the one-pot reaction of the O4S2 macrocycle L (Chart ) with CuI in both the absence and presence of KI. In the latter case, KI added with CuI induced not only the endocoordination of L to K+ but also the rearrangement of the copper(I) iodide cluster by coordination of I–. As an extension of the above investigations, we now report the synthesis and structural study of an extended series of complexes of L, incorporating the thiaphilic metal ions Ag+, Cu+, Hg2+, and Pd2+. For example, following the formation of an endocyclic monosilver(I) complex, the preparation and structural characterization of several dumbbell-shaped disilver(I) complexes linked by diamine-type coligands (dabco and bpp) proved possible. In addition, two coordination polymers are also reported incorporating exo- or endo-/exocoordination.
elements.clean_text: Related to the exocoordination based networking of thiamacrocycles, we have recently communicated homo- and heteronuclear coordination polymers with different motifs which were obtained from the one-pot reaction of the O4S2 macrocycle L  (Chart ) with CuI in both the absence and presence of KI. In the latter case, KI added with CuI induced not only the endocoordination of L to K+ but also the rearrangement of the copper(I) iodide cluster by coordination of I-. As an extension of the above investigations, we now report the synthesis and structural study of an extended series of complexes of L, incorporating the thiaphilic metal ions Ag+, Cu+, Hg2+, and Pd2+. For example, following the formation of an endocyclic monosilver(I) complex, the preparation and structural characterization of several dumbbell-shaped disilver(I) complexes linked by diamine-type coligands (dabco and bpp) proved possible. In addition, two coordination polymers are also reported incorporating exo- or endo-/exocoordination.

elements.content: L was synthesized as described previously by us. A comparative study of the interactions of L with the soft metal ions Cu+, Ag+, Hg2+, and Pd2+ has been carried out. The reactions of L with AgClO4, Hg(NO3)2, and K2PdCl4 in dichloromethane/methanol yielded the crystalline products 1–3, each with a 1:1 (metal-to-ligand) stoichiometry (Figure and Table ). In each complex, the metal ion lies inside the macrocyclic cavity but shows a different coordination arrangement. In contrast to the observed anion coordination in complexes 2 and 3, the perchlorate anion in 1 remains uncoordinated.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussions

Preparation and Structures of Endocyclic Mononuclear Complexes (1-3)

 L was synthesized as described previously by us. A comparative study of the interactions of L with the soft metal ions Cu+, Ag+, Hg2+, and Pd2+ has been carried out. The reactions of L with AgClO4, Hg(NO3)2, and K2PdCl4 in dichloromethane/methanol yielded the crystalline products 1-3, each with a 1:1 (metal-to-ligand) stoichiometry (Figure  and Table ). In each complex, the metal ion lies inside the macrocyclic cavity but shows a different coordination arrangement. In contrast to the observed anion coordination in complexes 2 and 3, the perchlorate anion in 1 remains uncoordinated.

When AgClO4 was employed, the mononuclear complex 1, showing the presence of two independent [AgL]ClO4 complex units incorporating very similar Ag coordination environments, was obtained (Figure a and ). In each cationic complex of type 1, the Ag atom located in the ring cavity is four-coordinate, being bound to the O2S2 donor set from L in a bent arrangement. The bite angles around the metal center vary considerably, ranging from 62.0(8)° (O3–Ag1–O4) to 158.3(4)° (S1–Ag1–S2), presumably due to the presence of the weak interactions Ag1···O1 [3.382(1) Å] and Ag1···O2 [4.102(1) Å]. Thus, the Ag coordination cannot be described in terms of a regular polyhedron. The Ag–S [2.432(1)–2.453(1) Å] and Ag–O [2.631(3)–2.740(3) Å] bond lengths are within the normal range for these bond types. The preferred anion-free mononuclear endocyclization in 1 presumably reflects the overall strong coordination of the donor set and the weak affinity of the ClO4 – for binding to this metal center.
elements.clean_text: When AgClO4 was employed, the mononuclear complex 1, showing the presence of two independent [AgL]ClO4 complex units incorporating very similar Ag coordination environments, was obtained (Figure a and ). In each cationic complex of type 1, the Ag atom located in the ring cavity is four-coordinate, being bound to the O2S2 donor set from L in a bent arrangement. The bite angles around the metal center vary considerably, ranging from 62.0(8)° (O3-Ag1-O4) to 158.3(4)° (S1-Ag1-S2), presumably due to the presence of the weak interactions Ag1⋅⋅⋅O1 [3.382(1) Å] and Ag1⋅⋅⋅O2 [4.102(1) Å]. Thus, the Ag coordination cannot be described in terms of a regular polyhedron. The Ag-S [2.432(1)-2.453(1) Å] and Ag-O [2.631(3)-2.740(3) Å] bond lengths are within the normal range for these bond types. The preferred anion-free mononuclear endocyclization in 1 presumably reflects the overall strong coordination of the donor set and the weak affinity of the ClO4 - for binding to this metal center.

elements.content: On reaction with Hg(NO3)2, L forms the dinitrato complex 2 with formula [HgL(NO3)2] (Figure b). Unlike 1, this complex is a neutral species. The Hg center in 2 is six-coordinated to an O2S2 donor set from L (but not to O2 and O2A) as well as to two monodentate nitrato ligands; the geometry of the Hg coordination sphere appears best described as distorted octahedral. The O2S2 donors of L define the square plane, with the axial positions occupied by two nitrato ligands [∠O3–Hg1–O3A 174.8(1)°]. Reported Hg–S(thioether) bond lengths fall in the range 2.4–2.8 Å. Thus, the Hg1–S1 bond of 2.426(1) Å is consistent with typical strong binding to the mercury center. However, the Hg1–O1(ether) bond [2.841(4) Å] shows a somewhat elongated length which is longer than that of the Hg1–O3(nitrate) bond [2.737(4) Å], suggesting that the negatively charged nitrato oxygen is bound more strongly to the Hg center.
elements.clean_text: On reaction with Hg(NO3)2, L forms the dinitrato complex 2 with formula [HgL(NO3)2] (Figure b). Unlike 1, this complex is a neutral species. The Hg center in 2 is six-coordinated to an O2S2 donor set from L (but not to O2 and O2A) as well as to two monodentate nitrato ligands; the geometry of the Hg coordination sphere appears best described as distorted octahedral. The O2S2 donors of L define the square plane, with the axial positions occupied by two nitrato ligands [∠O3-Hg1-O3A 174.8(1)°]. Reported Hg-S(thioether) bond lengths fall in the range 2.4-2.8 Å. Thus, the Hg1-S1 bond of 2.426(1) Å is consistent with typical strong binding to the mercury center. However, the Hg1-O1(ether) bond [2.841(4) Å] shows a somewhat elongated length which is longer than that of the Hg1-O3(nitrate) bond [2.737(4) Å], suggesting that the negatively charged nitrato oxygen is bound more strongly to the Hg center.

elements.content: Treatment of L with K2PdCl4 gave an orange complex 3 with the formula [PdLCl2] (Figure c). In this complex, as expected for Pd2+, the metal center attains a square-planar coordination geometry with the coordination sites occupied by two S donors from L and two Cl–. In this case, all four ether O atoms remain uncoordinated. The bond angles around Pd vary from 85.0(2) (S1–Pd1–S2) to 92.4(2)° (Cl1–Pd1–Cl2). On complexation, the macrocycle is significantly bent along the S1–Pd1–S2 axis to yield a V-shape. In contrast to the case of 2, two coordinated anions in 3 are located on the same side of the bound macrocycle (cis-form) with the Pd2+ positioned 1.683 Å from the cavity center (S1–S2 axis) toward the anions.
elements.clean_text: Treatment of L with K2PdCl4 gave an orange complex 3 with the formula [PdLCl2] (Figure c). In this complex, as expected for Pd2+, the metal center attains a square-planar coordination geometry with the coordination sites occupied by two S donors from L and two Cl-. In this case, all four ether O atoms remain uncoordinated. The bond angles around Pd vary from 85.0(2) (S1-Pd1-S2) to 92.4(2)° (Cl1-Pd1-Cl2). On complexation, the macrocycle is significantly bent along the S1-Pd1-S2 axis to yield a V-shape. In contrast to the case of 2, two coordinated anions in 3 are located on the same side of the bound macrocycle (cis-form) with the Pd2+ positioned 1.683 Å from the cavity center (S1-S2 axis) toward the anions.

elements.content: For complexes 1–3 the strong coordination of the S2-donor of L to the respective single metal centers thus appears to promote the formation of the observed endocyclic mononuclear species. With respect to anion-coordination ability, the occurrence of such coordination in complexes 2 and 3 likely reflects the stronger affinity of NO3 – and Cl– over ClO4 – (for 1) for the respective thiaphilic metal centers in these complexes. Reflecting this result, the anion-free cationic silver(I) complex 1 was employed as a metalloligand-type precursor in this work (see later).

With respect to anion-coordination ability, the occurrence of such coordination in complexes 2 and 3 likely reflects the stronger affinity of NO3 - and Cl- over ClO4 - (for 1) for the respective thiaphilic metal centers in these complexes. Reflecting this result, the anion-free cationic silver(I) complex 1 was employed as a metalloligand-type precursor in this work (see later).

elements.content: Having obtained the endocyclic mononuclear complexes, we proceeded to the preparation of related species with extended structures. As mentioned above, treatment of L with silver(I) perchlorate resulted in the formation of the anion-free mononuclear cationic complex 1 (Figure a), which might be expected to act as a metalloligand because of its unsaturated coordination sphere. Thus, it seemed of interest to prepare new complex types with extended structures through further reaction of 1 with diamine-type linker coligands such as dabco and bpp (Scheme ). Indeed, the 1-mediated stepwise reactions between 1 and the linker coligands produced the interesting dumbbell-type complexes 4 and 5 as coordinately linked macrocyclic disilver species (Route I). Furthermore, Route II exploits a straightforward one-pot reaction between L and AgClO4 in the presence of L′ that also resulted in the isolation of the corresponding dumbbell-type complexes 4 and 5.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation and Structures of Dumbbell-type Disilver Complexes (4 and 5)

Having obtained the endocyclic mononuclear complexes, we proceeded to the preparation of related species with extended structures. As mentioned above, treatment of L with silver(I) perchlorate resulted in the formation of the anion-free mononuclear cationic complex 1 (Figure a), which might be expected to act as a metalloligand because of its unsaturated coordination sphere. Thus, it seemed of interest to prepare new complex types with extended structures through further reaction of 1 with diamine-type linker coligands such as dabco and bpp (Scheme ). Indeed, the 1-mediated stepwise reactions between 1 and the linker coligands produced the interesting dumbbell-type complexes 4 and 5 as coordinately linked macrocyclic disilver species (Route I). Furthermore, Route II exploits a straightforward one-pot reaction between L and AgClO4 in the presence of L' that also resulted in the isolation of the corresponding dumbbell-type complexes 4 and 5.

elements.content: The coligand bpp was synthesized according to the procedure reported previously. The X-ray structure analyses of 4 and 5 incorporating different coligands confirm their 2:2:1 (L:Ag:L′) stoichiometry: [Ag2 L 2(dabco)](ClO4)2 (4) and [Ag2 L 2(bpp)](ClO4)2 (5) (Figure ). For each of 4 and 5, the structure consists of a dumbbell arrangement in which two mononuclear complex units (AgL)+ are linked by one coligand L′ to yield a [(LAg)-L′-(AgL)] arrangement via the formation two Ag–N bonds.
elements.clean_text: The coligand bpp was synthesized according to the procedure reported previously. The X-ray structure analyses of 4 and 5 incorporating different coligands confirm their 2:2:1 (L:Ag:L') stoichiometry: [Ag2 L 2(dabco)](ClO4)2 (4) and [Ag2 L 2(bpp)](ClO4)2 (5) (Figure ). For each of 4 and 5, the structure consists of a dumbbell arrangement in which two mononuclear complex units (AgL)+ are linked by one coligand L' to yield a [(LAg)-L'-(AgL)] arrangement via the formation two Ag-N bonds.

elements.content: In the dumbbell structures of 4 and 5, the coordination environment of each metal center provided by the macrocycle is similar to that in 1: each metal center is five-coordinated by O2S2 donors from L, with the two ether oxygen donors between two benzo units uncoordinated. The fifth site is occupied by an N atom from the coligand. Both of the silver(I) centers in 4 and 5 can be described as being in a distorted square pyramidal environment. The O2S2-donors of L form the square plane while one N atom in the coligand occupies the apex position.

In the above structures, the silver(I) centers are shielded from further interaction with solvent or anions by the dimeric bridging arrangement as well as by the folded complexed macrocycles. The Ag···Ag separations in 4 and 5 are 7.148(3) Å (4) and 15.601(4) Å (5). Consequently, the preferred structures obtained for these complexes appear to reflect the weaker coordination affinity of ClO4 – for silver(I), allowing the coligand to form Ag–N bonds with two silver centers. Parallel to the formation of these complexes, we have previously reported two dumbbell-type disilver(I) complexes of some smaller thiaoxamacrocycles linked by 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy). By using L in this work, once again, we were able to isolate the bpy-linked dumbbell analogue (). However, it is noteworthy that the spacer ligands dabco or bpp also form the stable dumbbell-type disilver(I) complexes 4 and 5 in spite of their shorter or longer length, which could be disadvantageous to form such a pattern because of the expected repulsive force or high flexibility. To the best of our knowledge, the dinuclear macrocyclic complexes linked by dabco or bpp coligand are unique.

elements.content: To provide insight into the nature of the dummbell complexes in solution state, comparative NMR studies were carried out for each complex type. The 1H NMR spectra of (a) L, (b) L + Ag+, (c) L + Ag+ + L′, and (d) L′ are shown in Figure for each coligand (L′) type. The signals of the five methylene (H1–H5) and the aromatic protons of L are well resolved (Figure a). In the case of L + AgClO4 (1.0 equiv) (Figure b), every proton of L, except H5, shows a large downfield shift, suggesting quite stable complex formation in this case. The order of magnitude of the induced chemical shifts is H3 (0.40 ppm) > H2 (0.25 ppm) > H1,4,5 (0–0.15 ppm), in accord with Ag+ being strongly bound by the sulfur donors and with the oxygen atoms interacting weakly with Ag+, as occurs in the solid state. On complexation with the coligand (L + AgClO4 + L′) (Figure c), the induced chemical shift for H6 (closest to the nitrogen donor) is greater than those of the other protons in each coligand (The spectra for L′ + AgClO4, which also exhibit the coordination induced chemical shifts of the coligands, are shown in ). These results are in agreement with the formation of the dumbbell-like complexes in solution that are similar to those found in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Comparative NMR Study of 4 and 5 

To provide insight into the nature of the dummbell complexes in solution state, comparative NMR studies were carried out for each complex type. The 1H NMR spectra of (a) L, (b) L + Ag+, (c) L + Ag+ + L', and (d) L' are shown in Figure  for each coligand (L') type. The signals of the five methylene (H1-H5) and the aromatic protons of L are well resolved (Figure a). In the case of L + AgClO4 (1.0 equiv) (Figure b), every proton of L, except H5, shows a large downfield shift, suggesting quite stable complex formation in this case. The order of magnitude of the induced chemical shifts is H3 (0.40 ppm) > H2 (0.25 ppm) > H1,4,5 (0-0.15 ppm), in accord with Ag+ being strongly bound by the sulfur donors and with the oxygen atoms interacting weakly with Ag+, as occurs in the solid state. On complexation with the coligand (L + AgClO4 + L') (Figure c), the induced chemical shift for H6 (closest to the nitrogen donor) is greater than those of the other protons in each coligand (The spectra for L' + AgClO4, which also exhibit the coordination induced chemical shifts of the coligands, are shown in ). These results are in agreement with the formation of the dumbbell-like complexes in solution that are similar to those found in the solid state.

elements.content: Having obtained the endocyclic mononuclear and dinuclear complexes in discrete form, the complexes 6 and 7 with 1D polymeric structures were prepared by reaction of L with CuBr and AgSCN, respectively (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation and Structures of the Exocyclic and Endo-/Exocyclic Complexes 6 and 7 

Having obtained the endocyclic mononuclear and dinuclear complexes in discrete form, the complexes 6 and 7 with 1D polymeric structures were prepared by reaction of L with CuBr and AgSCN, respectively (Scheme ).

elements.clean_text: 2  Formation of Exocyclic (6) and Endo-/Exocyclic (7) 1D Coordination Networks of L

elements.content: First, reaction of L with CuBr in dichloromethane/acetonitrile afforded the green crystalline complex 6. Contrasting with the discrete structures of 1–5, X-ray analysis revealed that 6 has a 1D double-stranded poly(cyclic dimer) network with formula {[(Cu2Br2)L 2]·2CH2Cl2} n (Figure ). The asymmetric unit of 6 contains one L, one Cu+, and one Br–. The successive ligand molecules are linked by a rhomboidal Cu2Br2 motif via Cu–S bonds, with the macrocycle adopting a highly twisted configuration. Each copper(I) coordination sphere is distorted tetrahedral, with the Cu-donor atom angles falling in the range 108(1)–122(2)° (Table ). The Cu–S bond distances [2.260(9) and 2.314(9) Å] fall in the lower part of the literature range for such bonds (2.23–2.90 Å). All oxygen donors of L are uncoordinated. Related to this network, an isostructural CuI complex of L has been previously reported by us.

elements.content: The reaction of L with AgSCN under similar conditions to that employed for the synthesis of 6 afforded the colorless crystalline product 7, which proved suitable for X-ray analysis. Unlike the exocyclic coordination mode in 6, compound 7 shows an unusal endo-/exocyclic 1D polymeric arrangement with the formula [Ag4 L 2(SCN)4] n (Figure , Table ). The asymmetric unit of 7 contains one L, two silver ions, and two thiocyanate ions. The gross geometry of 7 can be described as an infinite 1D fishbone-like pattern (Figure c).

The fishbone structure in this case incorporates a “looped” exocyclic backbone of type {Ag2-(1,3-μ2-SCN)2-Ag2-(1,1,3-μ3-SCN)-Ag2} n , constructed by the networking of Ag2 atoms and thiocyanato groups with the endocyclic Ag1 complexes containing the macrocycle units as pendants. An interesting feature of the backbone is the presence of two types of thiocyanato bridging groups: one acts as a 1,3-μ2-bidentate bridging ligand, and the other bridges via a 1,1,3-μ3-tridentate mode (Scheme ).

elements.clean_text: 3  Bridging Coordination Modes of the Thiocyanate Ion in 7

elements.content: The Ag2 atom in the backbone of 7 is four-coordinate, being bound to four thiocyanato ligands. Similar to the situation in the dumbbell-like disilver(I) complexes 4 and 5, the endocyclic Ag1 atom in 7 is five-coordinate, being bound to a O2S2 donor set from L in a twisted conformation and one thiocyanato ion. Two ether oxygens from L also interact weakly with silver: Ag1···O1 2.971(1) and Ag1···O2 3.334(1) Å. Recently, we reported a somewhat related leaf-shaped 1D supramolecular structure, in which a NS2-macrocylic Hg(II) complex unit is attached to a Hg–Br–Hg–Br single-chain backbone. To the best of our knowledge, 7 is the first example in which two types of thiocyanato bridging ligands, showing 1,3-μ2-bidentate and 1,1,3-μ3-tridentate modes, are alternatively linked to form a 1D “looped” backbone. We know of only one example exhibiting such a 1D looped backbone, {[Ag2(SCN)4]2–} n ; in this case, this anionic chain is separated from the accompaning cationic complex unit.
elements.clean_text: The Ag2 atom in the backbone of 7 is four-coordinate, being bound to four thiocyanato ligands. Similar to the situation in the dumbbell-like disilver(I) complexes 4 and 5, the endocyclic Ag1 atom in 7 is five-coordinate, being bound to a O2S2 donor set from L in a twisted conformation and one thiocyanato ion. Two ether oxygens from L also interact weakly with silver: Ag1⋅⋅⋅O1 2.971(1) and Ag1⋅⋅⋅O2 3.334(1) Å. Recently, we reported a somewhat related leaf-shaped 1D supramolecular structure, in which a NS2-macrocylic Hg(II) complex unit is attached to a Hg-Br-Hg-Br single-chain backbone. To the best of our knowledge, 7 is the first example in which two types of thiocyanato bridging ligands, showing 1,3-μ2-bidentate and 1,1,3-μ3-tridentate modes, are alternatively linked to form a 1D "looped" backbone. We know of only one example exhibiting such a 1D looped backbone, {[Ag2(SCN)4]2-} n ; in this case, this anionic chain is separated from the accompaning cationic complex unit.

elements.content: The O4S2-donor macrocycle L has been employed to synthesize thiaphilic metal complexes showing both different coordination modes (endo-, exo-, and endo/exo-) and topologies (mono-, di-, and polymeric). By using the anion-free monosilver(I) complex as a metalloligand, we were able to prepare dumbbell-type disilver(I) complexes on reaction with suitable diamine coligands. In addition, two unusal polymeric species based on exo- and endo-/exocyclic coordination as well as on the linking properties of the anion used were isolated. From these results, it is concluded that by employing the thiaphilicity of soft metals and their flexible coordination modes, in association with exocyclic coordination, it is possible to construct network species displaying a very considerable degree of sophistication. One of the challenging tasks or goals in this field comes from how the proposed endo- and exocyclic coordination might be controlled and how such behavior might be applied. Controllable endo-/exocoordination could be a starting point for developing metallosupramolecular materials that include sensors and switches.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The O4S2-donor macrocycle L has been employed to synthesize thiaphilic metal complexes showing both different coordination modes (endo-, exo-, and endo/exo-) and topologies (mono-, di-, and polymeric). By using the anion-free monosilver(I) complex as a metalloligand, we were able to prepare dumbbell-type disilver(I) complexes on reaction with suitable diamine coligands. In addition, two unusal polymeric species based on exo- and endo-/exocyclic coordination as well as on the linking properties of the anion used were isolated. From these results, it is concluded that by employing the thiaphilicity of soft metals and their flexible coordination modes, in association with exocyclic coordination, it is possible to construct network species displaying a very considerable degree of sophistication. One of the challenging tasks or goals in this field comes from how the proposed endo- and exocyclic coordination might be controlled and how such behavior might be applied. Controllable endo-/exocoordination could be a starting point for developing metallosupramolecular materials that include sensors and switches.

elements.content: All chemicals and solvents employed in the syntheses were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Mass spectra were obtained on a Thermo Scientific LCQ Fleet spectrometer. The FT-IR spectra were measured with a Shimadzu FT-IR 8100 spectrometer. The elemental analysis was carried out on a LECO CHNS-932 elemental analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

All chemicals and solvents employed in the syntheses were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. Mass spectra were obtained on a Thermo Scientific LCQ Fleet spectrometer. The FT-IR spectra were measured with a Shimadzu FT-IR 8100 spectrometer. The elemental analysis was carried out on a LECO CHNS-932 elemental analyzer.

CAUTION! Perchlorate salts of metal complexes are potentially explosive and should be handled with great care.

Preparation of <bold>1</bold>, [AgL]ClO<sub>4</sub>

Silver perchlorate (7.4 mg, 0.036 mmol) in methanol (2 mL) was added to a solution of L (15.0 mg, 0.036 mmol) in dichloromethane (2 mL). Slow evaporation of the solution afforded a colorless crystalline product 1 suitable for X-ray analysis. Mp: 194–195 °C (decomp.). IR (KBr pellet): 2922, 2874, 2361, 2345, 1598, 1587, 1492, 1451, 1421, 1293, 1249, 1189, 1089, 1022, 1007, 941, 758, 636, 624 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C22H28AgClO8S2: C, 42.08; H, 4.49. Found: C, 42.13; H, 4.51. Mass spectrum m/z (ESI): 527.03 [Ag(L)]+.

elements.content: All data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX2 ULTRA diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) generated by a rotating anode. Data collection, data reduction, and semiempirical absorption correction were carried out using the software package APEX2. All of the calculations for the structure determination were carried out using the SHELXTL package. In all cases, all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and all hydrogen atoms except coordinated water molecules were placed in idealized positions and refined isotropically in a riding manner along with their respective parent atoms. For coordinated water molecules, the initial positions of the hydrogen atoms were obtained from difference electron density maps and refined with riding constraints. Since compound 6 is slowly decomposed when exposed to air, it shows a larger R-value. Relevant crystal data collection and refinement data for the crystal structures are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Analysis

All data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX2 ULTRA diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) generated by a rotating anode. Data collection, data reduction, and semiempirical absorption correction were carried out using the software package APEX2. All of the calculations for the structure determination were carried out using the SHELXTL package. In all cases, all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and all hydrogen atoms except coordinated water molecules were placed in idealized positions and refined isotropically in a riding manner along with their respective parent atoms. For coordinated water molecules, the initial positions of the hydrogen atoms were obtained from difference electron density maps and refined with riding constraints. Since compound 6 is slowly decomposed when exposed to air, it shows a larger R-value. Relevant crystal data collection and refinement data for the crystal structures are summarized in Table .

cln_elements.content:
CAUTION! Perchlorate salts of metal complexes are potentially explosive and should be handled with great care.

Preparation of <bold>1</bold>, [AgL]ClO<sub>4</sub>

Silver perchlorate (7.4 mg, 0.036 mmol) in methanol (2 mL) was added to a solution of L (15.0 mg, 0.036 mmol) in dichloromethane (2 mL). Slow evaporation of the solution afforded a colorless crystalline product 1 suitable for X-ray analysis. Mp: 194–195 °C (decomp.). IR (KBr pellet): 2922, 2874, 2361, 2345, 1598, 1587, 1492, 1451, 1421, 1293, 1249, 1189, 1089, 1022, 1007, 941, 758, 636, 624 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C22H28AgClO8S2: C, 42.08; H, 4.49. Found: C, 42.13; H, 4.51. Mass spectrum m/z (ESI): 527.03 [Ag(L)]+.

Preparation of <bold>2</bold>, [HgL(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]

Mercury(II) nitrate (12.2 mg, 0.036 mmol) in methanol (2 mL) was added to a solution of L (15.0 mg, 0.036 mmol) in dichloromethane (2 mL). Slow evaporation of the solution afforded a colorless crystalline product 2 suitable for X-ray analysis. Mp: 138–139 °C (decomp.). IR (KBr, pellet): 2982, 2938, 2867, 1602, 1590, 1495, 1451, 1430, 1384, 1300, 1245, 1135, 1115, 1064, 1036, 949, 834, 752 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C22H28HgN2O10S2: C, 35.46; H, 3.79; N, 3.76. Found: C, 35.70; H, 3.66; N, 3.51. Mass spectrum m/z (ESI): 684.10 [Hg(L)(NO3)]+.

Preparation of <bold>3</bold>, [PdLCl<sub>2</sub>]

K2PdCl4 (5.8 mg, 0.018 mmol) in methanol was added to a solution of L (15.0 mg, 0.036 mmol) in dichloromethane (2 mL). Slow evaporation of the solution afforded an orange crystalline product 3 suitable for X-ray analysis. Mp: 249–250 °C (decomp.). IR (KBr, pellet): 2897, 2855, 1598, 1489, 1449, 1406, 1288, 1255, 1229, 1136, 1123, 1105, 1054, 934, 756, 744, 693 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C22H28Cl2O4PdS2: C, 44.19; H, 4.72. Found: C, 43.85; H, 4.59%. Mass spectrum m/z (ESI): 981.16 [ClPd(L)2]+.

Preparation of <bold>4</bold>, [Ag<sub>2</sub>L<sub>2</sub>(dabco)](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>

L (15.0 mg, 0.036 mmol), AgClO4 (7.4 mg, 0.036 mmol), and dabco (4.0 mg, 0.036 mmol) were dissolved in DMF. Vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into the DMF solution afforded a colorless crystalline product 4 suitable for X-ray analysis. Mp: 212–213 °C. IR (KBr, cm–1): 2933, 2907, 2870, 1599, 1588, 1496, 1450, 1295, 1246, 1192, 1131, 1105, 944, 931, 768, 623. Anal. Calcd for C50H68Ag2Cl2N2O16S4: C, 43.90; H, 5.01; N, 2.05. Found: C, 43.88; H, 5.03; N, 2.07.

Preparation of <bold>5</bold>, [Ag<sub>2</sub>L<sub>2</sub>(bpp)](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>

L (15.0 mg, 0.036 mmol), AgClO4 (7.4 mg, 0.036 mmol), and bpp (8.6 mg, 0.036 mmol) were dissolved in DMF. Vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into the DMF solution afforded a colorless crystalline product 5 suitable for X-ray analysis. Mp: 297–298 °C. IR (KBr, cm–1): 2910, 2838, 1671, 1595, 1540, 1508, 1441, 1396, 1248, 1233, 1082, 1004, 989, 948, 780, 742, 660, 624, 531 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C58H72Ag2Cl2N4O16S4: C, 46.56; H, 4.85. Found: C, 46.36; H, 4.63.

Preparation of <bold>6</bold>, {[(Cu<sub>2</sub>Br<sub>2</sub>)L<sub>2</sub>]·2CH<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>

A dichloromethane (2 mL) solution of L (15.0 mg, 0.036 mmol) was allowed to diffuse slowly into an acetonitrile (2 mL) solution of CuBr (10.2 mg, 0.036 mmol) in a capillary tube (i.d. 5 mm). Slow evaporation of the solution gave a green crystalline 6 that proved suitable for X-ray analysis. But compound 6 is slowly decomposed when exposed to air. Mp: 166–167 °C. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3054, 2931, 2871, 1597, 1585, 1489, 1449, 1349, 1241, 1230, 1124, 1106, 1066, 1038, 952, 755, 728 cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C24H32BrCl4CuO4S2: C, 39.28; H, 4.39; S, 8.74. Found: C, 38.92; H, 4.45; S, 8.91.

Preparation of <bold>7</bold>, [Ag<sub>4</sub>L<sub>2</sub>(SCN)<sub>4</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>

Silver thiacyanate (5.9 mg, 0.036 mmol) in methanol (2 mL) was added to a solution of L (15.0 mg, 0.036 mmol) in dichloromethane (2 mL). A colorless powder, which precipitated from the solution, was filtered off. Vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into the acetonitrile solution of the precipitate gave a colorless crystalline product 7 suitable for X-ray analysis. Mp: 129–130 °C (decomp.). IR (KBr, cm–1): 2916, 2854, 2100, 1596, 1586, 1497, 1449, 1292, 1241, 1190, 1129, 1109, 1061, 1045, 939, 752. Anal. Calcd for C24H28Ag2N2O4S4: C, 38.31; H, 3.75. Found: C, 38.55; H, 3.51.
